title: Magnetic fields - current carrying wires experimen

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Students are investigating the relationship between the distance between current carrying wires and the magnitude of the magnetic force exerted between the wires using the setup shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Two vertical wires, Wire <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Wire <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, are connected to power supplies (not shown) and carry currents in opposite directions. Each wire is attached to a board, and the board with Wire <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is connected to a stationary force sensor. The boards are held parallel to each other and the distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> between the wires can be adjusted. The students hypothesize that the force exerted by Wire <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> on Wire <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is proportional to the inverse of the square of the distance between the wires. (a) Describe a procedure for collecting data that could be used to determine the relationship between the magnitude of the magnetic force exerted on the wires and the distance between the wires. Include any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Students are investigating the relationship between the distance between current carrying wires and the magnitude of the magnetic force exerted between the wires using the setup shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Two vertical wires, Wire <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Wire <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, are connected to power supplies (not shown) and carry currents in opposite directions. Each wire is attached to a board, and the board with Wire <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is connected to a stationary force sensor. The boards are held parallel to each other and the distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> between the wires can be adjusted. The students hypothesize that the force exerted by Wire <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> on Wire <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is proportional to the inverse of the square of the distance between the wires. (a) Describe a procedure for collecting data that could be used to determine the relationship between the magnitude of the magnetic force exerted on the wires and the distance between the wires. Include any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.
(b) Describe what quantities could be graphed and how the graph could be analyzed to test their hypothesis.

The students want to determine an experimental value for the magnetic permeability of free space, null. The same experimental setup is used and the current <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> is the same for both wires, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The length <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math> of the wire segments fixed to the boards are measured. In this experiment the distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> between the wires is held fixed and the force is measured while the current <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math> is then varied. Using measured values of <math alttext="L equals 1.4 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.4</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math> and <math alttext="d equals 0.005 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.005</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math>, the students collect the data shown in the table.<math alttext="I, in amps" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>A</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="F, in millinewtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>mN</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="2.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.8</mn></math><math alttext="0.35" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.35</mn></math><math alttext="3.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3.2</mn></math><math alttext="0.60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.60</mn></math><math alttext="3.6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3.6</mn></math><math alttext="0.65" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.65</mn></math><math alttext="4.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.0</mn></math><math alttext="1.00" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.00</mn></math><math alttext="4.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.4</mn></math><math alttext="1.10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.10</mn></math>(c)i. Indicate what measured and/or calculated quantities could be graphed to yield a straight line that could be used to calculate a numerical value for <math alttext="mu sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. Use the blank columns in the table to list any calculated quantities you will graph other than the data provided.Horizontal Axis:__________ Vertical Axis:__________
ii. Plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i) on the graph provided. Clearly scale and label all axes, including units, as appropriate.
iii. Draw the best-fit line for the data graphed in part (c)(ii).

(d) Using the line drawn in part (c)(iii) and the measured values <math alttext="L equals 1.4 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.4</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> and <math alttext="d equals 0.005 meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.005</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> as needed, calculate the magnetic permeability of free space, <math alttext="mu sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>μ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>.

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
